quotes.text: We show up four to eight people total pretend to be some company with some outcome problem. Rule one is you do not work at Stripe and rule two is we're not here to solve any problems. This is just about practicing empathy for the customer.

quotes.context: A replicable methodology (study groups) for training product intuition by separating empathy-building from solutioning.

quotes.topic_title: Learning mindset: choosing the hardest class

quotes.context: A contrarian learning mindset that prioritizes growth by deliberately choosing environments where you’re challenged most.

quotes.topic_title: Learning mindset: choosing the hardest class

quotes.topic_title: Learning mindset: choosing the hardest class

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With all the tools you need in one simple to use platform, Pendo makes it easy to answer critical questions about how users are engaging with your product and then turn those insights into action.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an end-to-end workflow: instrument product usage, learn from it, and operationalize changes quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes behavior-based analytics as the foundation for improving product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Then Pendo integrates user feedback so that you can capture and analyze what people actually want.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Pairs quantitative usage data with qualitative feedback to reduce blind spots in product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'm not surprised at all that over 10,000 companies use it today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point that signals market validation and scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Feedback is not used just as a way to prioritize what to build, but also as a tool that creates trust with all stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: From liberal arts to computer science switch
quotes.text: English was my selected major in school, but then I kept playing with computers and I kept liking math and I looked at the roles of the backgrounds of the people who were running the types of companies I loved.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical career-navigation heuristic: follow your intrinsic interests and study the backgrounds of leaders in the companies you aspire to.

quotes.topic_title: From liberal arts to computer science switch
quotes.text: At the time Facebook was getting super phenomenally successful. Apple was already on their up and up again and everyone who was leading those places had technical backgrounds and I liked computers a lot, so I added computer science as an engineering degree midway through school.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A concrete example of using industry signals and role-model patterns to justify a decisive midstream pivot into a technical track.

quotes.topic_title: From liberal arts to computer science switch
quotes.text: So it was a journey, but I had to make a pretty big switch in the middle to get on that path.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive idea that meaningful career alignment may require a major change mid-course rather than incremental tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Go-go-go urgency plus long-term compounding
quotes.text: We will do the work the night before it's due, so let's just make it due tomorrow. Can we turn tomorrow into today?
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical urgency tactic: pull deadlines forward to force focus and accelerate execution.

quotes.topic_title: Go-go-go urgency plus long-term compounding
quotes.text: So just optimistically seeing if we can just inject energy to go, go, go has produced surprising results and I think it ignites in other people that same interest and then it feeds off each other.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A leadership model where optimism and urgency create a contagious, compounding team momentum loop.

quotes.topic_title: Go-go-go urgency plus long-term compounding
quotes.text: They're going to require layers of infrastructure and services and applications and UI and partnerships that really look like that iceberg drawing you see where you just see the top, but then there's the whole thing underneath
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why durable product progress depends on deep, often-invisible foundational work.

quotes.topic_title: Go-go-go urgency plus long-term compounding
quotes.text: We'll never regret spending time making the latency of our payments APIs at Stripe faster. We'll never regret making it more reliable to send 83B election mails to the IRS.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A concrete heuristic for long-term compounding: invest in improvements that are universally valuable and hard to undo.

quotes.topic_title: Go-go-go urgency plus long-term compounding
quotes.text: Then the trick is how do you mix this go, go, go attitude with a long-term compounding? That's something I still struggle with, but I try to purposely balance it more than I used to.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A candid operating principle: intentionally balance speed with durable investments rather than defaulting to one mode.

quotes.topic_title: Example: scaling global payment methods at Stripe
quotes.text: for the first seven or eight years of Stripe, well prior to my being here, the incremental country ads and the incremental new payment methods was relatively flat over time and that was surprising to all of us who worked here because the world wanted it and we had a lot of people working on it and we were working very hard, but it wasn't producing returns in the way that we wanted.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Highlights a key scaling signal: lots of effort and demand can still yield flat output, indicating a structural bottleneck rather than an execution problem.

quotes.topic_title: Example: scaling global payment methods at Stripe
quotes.text: the optimistic as soon as possible go-go attitude was not working.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A concise counterpoint to default startup urgency—sometimes speed-first execution is the wrong strategy for complex scaling problems.

quotes.topic_title: Example: scaling global payment methods at Stripe
quotes.text: So we had to step back and say, "Well, what is the world going to look like in 10 years? What was going to need to be true and how can we start to go there now?"
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical long-horizon planning framework: define the 10-year end state, identify prerequisites, then backcast into present-day actions.

quotes.topic_title: Example: scaling global payment methods at Stripe
quotes.text: Which meant going a lot slower, building internal platforms, sending people around the world to start to build these payment methods, uproot their lives, pay for their apartments, get them on airplanes, start using these payment methods actually in the world.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Concrete methodology for nonlinear scaling: invest in platforms and on-the-ground immersion rather than one-off, linear integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Example: scaling global payment methods at Stripe
quotes.text: And now Stripe accepts over 100. So we got to 50 really quickly and then skyrocketed to 100.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A specific scaling outcome illustrating the payoff of compounding investments—once the platform and process exist, growth becomes nonlinear.

quotes.topic_title: Craft and quality: avoid building non-essential products
quotes.text: I think craft is a dessert that you get after the meal of does your thing solve a real problem in the world and are people clamoring, needing it badly?
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for sequencing product work: validate urgent need before investing heavily in polish and delight.

quotes.topic_title: Craft and quality: avoid building non-essential products
quotes.text: I missed a huge moment that I should have pounced on, which is that during those 20 minutes, our customers weren't furious.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive PMF signal: if an outage doesn’t trigger strong customer pain, the product may not be mission-critical.

quotes.topic_title: Craft and quality: avoid building non-essential products
quotes.text: But certainly there is no amount of craft, there is no amount of beauty, there's no amount delight or touches you can add to a thing that will solve the problem we had at our startup, which is that people didn't really need this.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A hard constraint practitioners can apply: quality can’t compensate for lack of real customer need.

quotes.topic_title: Craft and quality: avoid building non-essential products
quotes.text: People don't really get out of bed for their second problem. They get out of bed for their first problem.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic for choosing what to build: focus on the customer’s top pain, not nice-to-have improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Craft and quality: avoid building non-essential products
quotes.text: And you have to carefully listen and not pitch your customer or your prospective customer as you're trying to figure this out.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Practical discovery guidance: avoid selling during research so you can accurately learn what customers truly need.

quotes.topic_title: Customer conversations: stop pitching, use silence
quotes.text: People don't really get out of bed for their second problem. They get out of bed for their first problem.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for prioritization: customers are driven by their single most urgent pain, not a list of nice-to-haves.

quotes.topic_title: Customer conversations: stop pitching, use silence
quotes.text: And you have to carefully listen and not pitch your customer or your prospective customer as you're trying to figure this out.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Actionable advice that pitching too early blocks discovery of the real problem worth building for.

quotes.topic_title: Customer conversations: stop pitching, use silence
quotes.text: And it's not the customer's job to interrupt you and say, "Hey, could you stop your pitch? I want to tell you about my top problem."
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that if you dominate the conversation, you’ll never hear the truth—and customers won’t correct you.

quotes.topic_title: Customer conversations: stop pitching, use silence
quotes.text: And sometimes I'll prompt our customers, I'll say, "Hey, do you mind just opening up your email? What's in there?" Or, "If you weren't talking to me right now, what would you be working on?" Or, "Hey, last week, what grinds your gears? What are you not looking forward to?" Or magic wand, "What do you wish you could just have off your plate immediately? Forget Stripe, forget about thing, work on just in your whole life. What is it that you do not want to be doing?" Or, "A massive opportunity you wish was just one door away?"
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical set of open-ended prompts practitioners can use to surface real pain without anchoring the customer to your product pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Customer conversations: stop pitching, use silence
quotes.text: And so via silence, you can just create your roadmap pretty quickly and drop a lot of the long UXR, long survey, long build cycle approach.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A methodology claim: using silence and deep listening in conversations can accelerate roadmap discovery versus heavier research processes.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer access: Twitter, texting, and fast loops
quotes.text: And so the fact that people wouldn't be listening to their customers and really jumping through the computer to talk to them surprises me.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A contrarian push to remove organizational distance and proactively reach customers directly rather than relying on intermediated research.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer access: Twitter, texting, and fast loops
quotes.text: I think some of it is my own fear that I'm going to make the same mistake I've made in the past, which is build something that people like they're using but isn't solving a burning enough problem such that they're going to stop their day, they're going to tell their friends, we're going to be able to sustain the company economically over a long period of time.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical bar for prioritization: optimize for “burning problems” that drive interruption, word-of-mouth, and durable economics—not just usage.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer access: Twitter, texting, and fast loops
quotes.text: At Stripe, I'm able to quickly grab an engineer and hop on a call. I can forward a message over to a Slack group. And they know that because the customer's speaking directly, it somewhat trumps everything that's happening during the day.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: An actionable operating tactic: pull engineers into live customer conversations and treat direct customer input as higher priority than internal meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer access: Twitter, texting, and fast loops
quotes.text: We could go to our meeting where we're going to guess what the customer wants or we could talk to them directly.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A memorable decision rule that challenges default planning rituals: replace speculative alignment with direct customer contact.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer access: Twitter, texting, and fast loops
quotes.text: And you don't need 10,000 of those people to talk to. If you're text message friendly with five or 10 of those, you are going to have so much direct signal about where to go that you forget how you did it in the past.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A high-signal sampling methodology: cultivate a small set of representative, forward-looking customers for rapid, ongoing feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics: respond fast and turn detractors into promoters
quotes.text: Speed is an important one, which is just reducing the time between the moment the customer felt compelled enough to go out of their way to talk about some problem.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A simple, actionable definition of “speed” as a customer-feedback tactic: minimize latency from customer pain to your response.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics: respond fast and turn detractors into promoters
quotes.text: That should be P-zero alert level intensity.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A memorable prioritization rule: treat customer-reported issues as a P0-level trigger for immediate action.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics: respond fast and turn detractors into promoters
quotes.text: Even if it's, "Hey, I got this. I'm about to go to dinner. Can I hit you up tomorrow?" They're like, "Oh yeah, thank you. Awesome. I can't even believe you responded."
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Shows how a fast, human acknowledgment (even without a solution yet) can dramatically change customer sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics: respond fast and turn detractors into promoters
quotes.text: And in those situations, my bar for how we will respond to those folks is not to just solve the problem, but it is to turn them into a promoter, and most of the time we're able to, even if there was a pretty relevant issue.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A higher-than-usual support goal that reframes incident response from damage control to advocacy creation.

quotes.topic_title: Tactics: respond fast and turn detractors into promoters
quotes.text: I remember one time at Atlas, we had this bug in which for a handful of our legal docs, they were handing out let's say, 25 shares rather than 25% of the shares. We dropped the percentage sign, and thankfully a founder noticed this in the docs and tweeted about it.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A concrete example of a high-stakes product bug that illustrates why rapid response and follow-up matter.

quotes.topic_title: Managing feedback volume: self-selection and time-boxed programs
quotes.text: Otherwise, you can tell folks, "This is really awesome. Do you mind sending me an email with three to five bullet points about the details of how you got to this issue?" And that's not a 30-minute meeting. You don't need to blow up your whole life to get on the phone with them. It's not a huge homework assignment to them, but it's enough structure that it will self-select those who want to go deep, and then from there, you really do owe it to them to follow up if they're going to be that detailed.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A lightweight, structured ask (bullets/screenshots) creates self-selection so you can prioritize the most engaged, high-signal feedback without endless meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Managing feedback volume: self-selection and time-boxed programs
quotes.text: I will happily respond to folks with, "I really appreciate that. Do you mind sending me a screenshot or a video?" And some of them don't. Okay, that's fine.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Raising the effort bar filters out low-signal reports while keeping the door open for serious users to provide actionable detail.

quotes.topic_title: Managing feedback volume: self-selection and time-boxed programs
quotes.text: It's just giving people permission through a program, even if it is deeply arbitrary, I find helps with bounding it, and then later I can follow up with the world, "Hey, we ran our first program, we got 65 videos," which we did. "We found dozens of issues," which we did. It was an incredibly valuable use of our time and it really came from just a single tweet.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Time-boxed “programs” (even ad hoc) can bound feedback intake and produce high-volume structured input fast, with concrete results to share back.

quotes.topic_title: Managing feedback volume: self-selection and time-boxed programs
quotes.text: I think most entrepreneurs would purchase that problem as a state.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing: being overwhelmed by customer interest is a high-quality problem that signals real product value.

quotes.topic_title: Only trust feedback from real paying customers
quotes.text: But you need to figure out, is that actually your customer, or is that your friend trying it? Who is actually your target customer exactly? Not a company or a segment, not digital natives that are X big. I'm talking about Sarah in this department, who has these tabs open and just faced this problem and needs to solve it by 4:00 PM. That level of specificity.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A concrete targeting framework: define the real user with situational specificity rather than broad personas or segments.

quotes.topic_title: Only trust feedback from real paying customers
quotes.text: Oftentimes, if you listen with enough silence, they might even say, "I'll pay you money to solve, blah." If you sit there long enough in silence.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical interview technique: use silence to surface explicit willingness-to-pay and the true problem statement.

quotes.topic_title: Only trust feedback from real paying customers
quotes.text: We discount all of that feedback from our friends to zero. That is not of interest to us. We don't even write it down. It's just not part of what we're talking about at all.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A contrarian operating rule to avoid being misled by friendly beta feedback and stay focused on real customers.

quotes.topic_title: Only trust feedback from real paying customers
quotes.text: And then the paying part is a forcing function because again, even with Sarah, because you're paying attention to her and solving her problem a bit, she'll say, "Of course, oh, this is great. I want feature X, Y and Z. Can it do one, two, and three?" Naturally, she would say that. But if you said, "And by the way, this thing is $10,000. We'll happily refund your money 100% the second you don't like it," she might say, "Whoa, whoa, wait a second. Yeah, I like this thing, but not $10, 000. For $10,000, it would need to solve X." And you're like, "Oh, there it is."
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A pricing-as-validation methodology: putting a real price on the table reveals what value is truly required versus nice-to-have requests.

quotes.topic_title: Forcing commitment: charge now, even $1
quotes.text: I would say the same thing, which is, "If we're super serious about this, send us $1 million. Wire us $1 million. We'll happily wire it back anytime you need it, but let's actually put some stake in the ground about the value."
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A forcing function for real commitment (even refundable) to avoid wasting time building for non-serious enterprise requests.

quotes.topic_title: Forcing commitment: charge now, even $1
quotes.text: And by the way, ready to pay is different than paying. Significantly different, significantly different.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A contrarian distinction that challenges “verbal willingness to pay” as a reliable signal.

quotes.topic_title: Forcing commitment: charge now, even $1
quotes.text: Paying is an independent group of people saying, "My problem is burning enough that I'm willing to exchange something I have that has value for the promise of what you're going to do."
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A crisp definition of payment as the strongest validation signal—value exchange under urgency.

quotes.topic_title: Forcing commitment: charge now, even $1
quotes.text: I'll say, "Feel free to sign up for any invoicing or payment service. I don't really care which one. You're welcome to choose Stripe if it's easy enough for you, I'd love to hear your two cents, and send me an invoice or a payment link for $1 right now, right now. That way, when it comes time to actually charge your first customer, it won't be your first time. It won't feel weird. You'll have already done this, you already have a dollar in your account, you already have your logo on the top right of the invoice. It'll feel great."
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical rehearsal tactic to normalize charging behavior and reduce founder discomfort before real sales.

quotes.topic_title: Metrics philosophy: measure customer value, not internal activity
quotes.text: I somewhat walk around with the belief that the product manager's responsibility is to produce product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A crisp framing of the PM’s core job that can guide metric selection and prioritization toward PMF outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Metrics philosophy: measure customer value, not internal activity
quotes.text: Charts that showcase things are going up into the right on one hand, and then tweets on the other.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for balancing quantitative trends with qualitative customer signal to assess PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Metrics philosophy: measure customer value, not internal activity
quotes.text: I think metrics at their best are a numerical representation of the value we're providing for the customer.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for choosing metrics that reflect customer value rather than internal activity.

quotes.topic_title: Metrics philosophy: measure customer value, not internal activity
quotes.text: One could measure anything. You can just start counting events and log lines. We've made it incredibly cheap to count stuff. And so, now we have this big privilege of choosing what to measure.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that the hard part isn’t instrumentation—it’s making deliberate choices about what matters.

quotes.topic_title: Metrics philosophy: measure customer value, not internal activity
quotes.text: Another reason why I spend a lot of time crafting a small number of these metrics is, they force trade-offs and decisions.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: A practical methodology: use a small set of metrics to drive alignment and resolve prioritization debates.

quotes.topic_title: Atlas metric case study: zero-support-ticket success rate
quotes.text: And so, we suggested this metric to ourselves, companies that have no support tickets through the incorporation service.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Defines a customer-centric, outcome-based metric that directly proxies whether users would recommend the product.

quotes.topic_title: Atlas metric case study: zero-support-ticket success rate
quotes.text: And if you get through that whole thing with no support tickets, that's a yes. If you have any number of support tickets, that's a no.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Shows a binary success metric that avoids averages and forces focus on end-to-end customer experience.

quotes.topic_title: Atlas metric case study: zero-support-ticket success rate
quotes.text: And we just looked at the percentage of founders that were going through the service with zero support tickets, which is very different than looking at an average, right? You could have the average as 0.3, but that doesn't necessarily mean that they're getting to 0.2 is going to cause them to tell their friends more.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Challenges conventional reliance on averages by arguing for a threshold-based metric tied to word-of-mouth behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Atlas metric case study: zero-support-ticket success rate
quotes.text: And over about 18 months, we took that number from 15% to 85. We basically just flipped it. And you can look at the market share plotted on the same timeframe and it's the same shape.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Provides a concrete before/after data point linking metric improvement to market share movement.

quotes.topic_title: Atlas metric case study: zero-support-ticket success rate
quotes.text: And I think you have to find a measure by which it speaks directly to what the customer wanted, and that if you accidentally leaked your dashboard to them, your customer would be ecstatic to learn that that's what you were measuring the whole time.
quotes.speaker: Jeff Weinstein
quotes.context: Offers a memorable test for choosing metrics: customers should be delighted by what you optimize.
